definitions.definition: To try to see , to pay attention to with one’s eyes .

subdefinitions.definition: As an intransitive verb, often with "at".
examples: They kept looking at me.
Don’t look in the closet.

subdefinitions.definition: As a transitive verb, often in the imperative ; chiefly takes relative clause as direct object.
examples: Look what you did to him!
Look who's back!
It looks as if it’s going to rain soon. or It looks like it’s going to rain soon. or It looks like rain [is coming].
or
or
Our new boss looks to be friendly.
It looks as if [ or like] I'm stuck with you.
or
You didn't use to look so dismal, but now you look /are look ing positively unhappy.
( UK ) He always looks like scoring a goal if not two.

definitions.definition: To give an appearance of being.
examples: That painting looks nice.
You’re looking worried. Whaddya thinking about?
You looked a fool when you slipped on a banana peel.

definitions.definition: To search for, to try to find .
To face or present a view.
examples: The hotel looks over the valleys of the HinduKush.
I look to each hour for my lover’s arrival.

definitions.definition: To express or manifest by a look.
To make sure of, to see to.

examples: Look out of the window [i.e. lean out] while I speak to you.

definitions.definition: To check , to make sure (of something).
To look at; to turn the eyes toward.
To influence, overawe, or subdue by looks or presence.
examples: to look down opposition

definitions.definition: To look at a pitch as a batter without swinging at it.
examples: The fastball caught him looking.
Clem Labine struck Mays out looking at his last at bat.
It's unusual for Mays to strike out looking . He usually takes a cut at it.

main_definition: To try to see , to pay attention to with one’s eyes .
secondary_definitions: ( copulative ) To give an appearance of being.
( intransitive , often with "for" ) To search for, to try to find .
To face or present a view.
( transitive ) To express or manifest by a look.
( transitive , often with "to" ) To make sure of, to see to.
( dated , sometimes figurative ) To show oneself in looking.
( transitive , archaic or dialectal ) To check , to make sure (of something).
( transitive , obsolete ) To look at; to turn the eyes toward.
( transitive , obsolete ) To seek ; to search for.
( transitive , obsolete ) To influence, overawe, or subdue by looks or presence.
( baseball ) To look at a pitch as a batter without swinging at it.
